facts.text: Appeal by special leave preferred against judgment and order of High Court of Bombay in reference under section 66(1) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is preferred against the judgment and order of the High Court of Bombay in a reference made to it by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal under section 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: Question referred to High Court: Whether commission of Rs. 2,45,557 was exempt in hands of assessee by virtue of Notification No. 878F dated March 21,1922, as amended by Notification No. 8 dated March 24, 1928.

anchor.surface_text: The following question was referred to the High Court Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the companymission of Rs. 2,45,557 was exempt in the hands of the assessee by virtue of the Notification No. 878F dated March 21,1922, as amended by Notification No. 8 dated March 24, 1928 ?

facts.text: S. P. Gallini was doing business in art-silk in the name and style of Rayon Yarns Import Company.

anchor.surface_text: One S. P. Gallini was dosing business in art-silk in the name and style of Rayon Yarns Import Company.

facts.text: Under agreement dated May 30, 1948, Gallini appointed E. Francescanto, the respondent, as his manager.

anchor.surface_text: Under an agreement dated May 30, 1948, he appointed E. Francescanto, the respondent, as his manager.

facts.text: For assessment year 1949-50, Gallini claimed deduction of Rs. 2,45,557 commission paid to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1949-50 Gallini claimed a deduction of Rs. 2,45,557 the companymission paid by him to the respondent in terms of the agreement, from his taxable in companye.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected Gallini's claim for deduction of commission.

anchor.surface_text: But the Income-tax Officer a rejected the claim on the ground that the payment of companymission is but a way to reduce his income and his tax liability.

facts.text: ITO held that commission payment was to reduce income and tax liability, profits divided between Gallini and respondent to evade income-tax, amount included in Gallini's taxable income.

anchor.surface_text: That is to say, in effect and substance he held that the profits of the said companypany were divided between Gallini, the employer, and the respondent, his employee, to evade income-tax and, therefore, the said amount was to be included in the taxable income of the employer.

facts.text: Department assessed the commission income in hands of assessee after assessing in hands of employer for AY 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: After having assessed the said amount in the hands of the employer for the assessment year 1949-50, the department sought to assess the said income over again in the hands of the assessee as companymission received by him from his employer.

facts.text: Assessee claimed exemption based on Notification No. 878F dated March 21, 1922, amended by No. 8 dated March 24, 1928.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee claimed exemption on the basis of the Notification No. 878F dated March 21, 1922, as amended by Notification No. 8 dated March 24, 1928.

facts.text: ITO rejected assessee's exemption claim.

anchor.surface_text: The claim was rejected.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner affirmed ITO's conclusion.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner came to the same companyclusion as the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal held that conditions of notification fulfilled and assessee entitled to exemption.

anchor.surface_text: On further appeal, the Appellate Tribunal, Bombay held that the companyditions laid down by the said numberification had been fulfilled and that the assessee was entitiled to the exemption claimed by him.

facts.text: At instance of revenue, question referred to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the revenue, the aforesaid question was referred to the High Court for its opinion.

facts.text: High Court agreed with Tribunal and answered question in affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court agreed with the Appellate Tribunal and answered the question in the affirmative.

facts.text: Revenue counsel contended assessee did not fulfill conditions of notification.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Desai, learned companynsel for the revenue, companytended that, in order to qualify for the exemption under the aforesaid numberification the assessee had to fulfill the companyditions laid down therein, that he had number fulfilled any one of them and that, therefore, he was number entitled to any exemption.

facts.text: Commission of Rs. 2,45,557 calculated as 1/2% on value of sales from 1st June 1948 to 31st January 1949 per agreement para 9(b).

anchor.surface_text: The agreement entered into between Gallini and the respondent is dated May 30, 1948. The relevant part of paragraph 9 b  of the agreement reads If your services are number discontinued on or before 31st January, 1949, you will be entitled to companymission 1/2  half of one per cent.  upon the value of all sales resulted on or after 1st June, 1948, and up to 31st January, 1949, except direct sales effected by the makers to other than to ourselves.

facts.text: ITO added commission Rs. 2,45,557 to Gallini's disclosed profits and assessed total Rs. 7,74,454.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer added the companymission of Rs. 2,45,557 to the profits disclosed by the employer and assessed the total sum of Rs. 7,74,454 to tax.

facts.text: Supreme Court held all three conditions of notification satisfied, assessee entitled to exemption.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, as all the three companyditions laid down by the numberification had been companyplied with, the assessee was entitled to exemption from tax in respect of the said companymission.

facts.text: Third condition satisfied: amount disallowed in Gallini's assessment and assessed under business head.

anchor.surface_text: In the instant case, admittedly, the third companydition was satisfied, for in assessing Gallini the said amount was disallowed in the companyputation of the profits of the business and had been assessed and charged under the head business in his hands.

facts.text: Commission paid out of profits of business as per ITO finding accepted by Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: But, though under the agreement the companymission payable to the assessee had to be calculated at a certain percentage on the gross turnover of the business, we find that the companymission was in fact paid out of the profits of the business.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant part of the numberification reads The following classes of income shall be exempt from the tax payable under the said Act, but shall be taken into account in determining the total income of an assessee for the purposes of the said Act Sums received by an assessee on account of salary, bonus, companymission or other remuneration for services rendered, or in lieu of interest on money advanced to a person for the purpose of his business. Where such sums have been paid out of, or determined with reference to the profits of such business, and by reason of such mode of payment or determination, have number been allowed as a deduction but have been assessed and charged under the head business.

concepts.interpretation: Three cumulative conditions: (i) paid out of or determined with reference to profits of business; (ii) not allowed as deduction but included in profits; (iii) assessed and charged under head 'business'

anchor.surface_text: At the outset we may point out that the first argument advanced by Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri is number available to him. The entire proceedings up to number went on the basis that the companymission was the income of the assessee, but he was entitled to an exemption under the said numberification. The question referred by the Tribunal to the High Court was also related to the exemption under the said numberification. If his argument be accepted, numberquestion of exemption under the numberification would arise, as the income was number the income of the assessee but of his employer. That question number having been referred to the High Court, it is number open to the assessee to raise it for the first time before us.

issues.text: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the commission of Rs. 2,45,557 was exempt in the hands of the assessee by virtue of the Notification No. 878F dated March 21,1922, as amended by Notification No. 8 dated March 24, 1928?

anchor.surface_text: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the commission of Rs. 2,45,557 was exempt in the hands of the assessee by virtue of the Notification No. 878F dated March 21,1922, as amended by Notification No. 8 dated March 24, 1928 ?

issues.text: Whether the assessee could argue that the commission was not his income but continued to be the income of the employer, as that was a new plea not raised in the referred question

anchor.surface_text: At the outset we may point out that the first argument advanced by Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri is not available to him. The entire proceedings up to now went on the basis that the commission was the income of the assessee, but he was entitled to an exemption under the said notification.

issues.text: Whether the conditions laid down in the notification were complied with

anchor.surface_text: The answer to the question referred to the High Court depends upon the terms of the said notification and the fact whether the conditions of the said notification were complied with.

issues.text: Whether the first condition was satisfied: the said sum has been paid out of or determined with reference to the profits of such business

anchor.surface_text: Under this notification commission received by an assessee is exempt from tax if the following three conditions are satisfied i the said sum has been paid out of or determined with reference to the profits of such business

issues.text: Whether the second condition was satisfied: the said amount has not been allowed as a deduction but has been included in the profits of the business

anchor.surface_text: ii the said amount has not been allowed as a deduction but has been included in the profits of the business and

issues.text: Whether the third condition was satisfied: income-tax has been assessed and charged on the said profits including the said income under the head business

anchor.surface_text: iii income-tax has been assessed and charged on the said profits including the said income under the head business.

Viswanatha Sastri, learned companynsel for the assessee, argued that, as the employer had been assessed on the same income as was number assessed in the hands of the employee presumably on the ground that the division of profits was sham and that the said income companytinued to be the income of the employer, the revenue companyld number assess the said income to tax once again as the income of the assessee, as in fact it never became his income.

The entire proceedings up to number went on the basis that the companymission was the income of the assessee, but he was entitled to an exemption under the said numberification.

arguments.claim: Notification exempts commission if three cumulative conditions satisfied: (i) paid out of/determined ref profits; (ii) not deducted but included in profits; (iii) assessed under business head

anchor.surface_text: The relevant part of the numberification reads The following classes of income shall be exempt from the tax payable under the said Act, but shall be taken into account in determining the total income of an assessee for the purposes of the said Act Sums received by an assessee on account of salary, bonus, companymission or other remuneration

arguments.claim: Object of notification is to prevent double taxation on same income

anchor.surface_text: The three companyditions are cumulative and unless all the three companyditions are satisfied numberexemption can be given. The object of the numberification is self-evident it is to prevent imposition of tax on the same income twice over.

arguments.claim: Third condition satisfied as amount disallowed in computation of Gallini's business profits and assessed under business head

anchor.surface_text: In the instant case, admittedly, the third companydition was satisfied, for in assessing Gallini the said amount was disallowed in the companyputation of the profits of the business and had been assessed and charged under the head business in his hands.

arguments.claim: High Court reasoning on first condition unsound; incomings not equal to profits as capital and overheads involved

anchor.surface_text: In our view, this reasoning is number sound. It is number possible to say that the entire incomings of the employers business were profits. There must have been a capital, however little, invested in the business and overhead charges must have been incurred in carrying out the business.

arguments.claim: First condition satisfied as commission in fact paid out of profits per ITO finding that it was part of profits to evade tax, accepted by Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: But, though under the agreement the companymission payable to the assessee had to be calculated at a certain percentage on the gross turnover of the business, we find that the companymission was in fact paid out of the profits of the business. The Income-tax Officer added the companymission of Rs. 2,45,557

arguments.court_reasoning: Tribunal finding not to be disturbed absent contrary evidence

arguments.claim: Second condition satisfied as commission not allowed as deduction to employer but included in his profits

anchor.surface_text: The second companydition was also fulfilled in this case, for, though the employer claimed the companymission paid to the assessee as a deduction, the Income-tax Officer included that amount in the profits of the business and assessed that income to tax.

arguments.claim: All three conditions complied with so assessee entitled to exemption

anchor.surface_text: In this view, as all the three companyditions laid down by the numberification had been companyplied with, the assessee was entitled to exemption from tax in respect of the said companymission.

arguments.claim: Precedents do not lay down universal principle; whether paid from profits fact-specific; here similar to Balakrishnan v. CIT

anchor.surface_text: We shall number numberice briefly the decisions cited at the bar. ... The decision in Balakrishnan v. Commissioner of Income-tax is directly in point, for in that case under circumstances similar to those in the present one, it was held that the companymission was paid out of the profits.

holdings.text: The first argument advanced by Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri is not available to him as the entire proceedings went on the basis that the commission was the income of the assessee but entitled to exemption under the notification, and the referred question related only to exemption; it is not open to raise it for the first time before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: At the outset we may point out that the first argument advanced by Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri is number available to him. The entire proceedings up to number went on the basis that the companymission was the income of the assessee, but he was entitled to an exemption under the said numberification. The question referred by the Tribunal to the High Court was also related to the exemption under the said numberification. If his argument be accepted, numberquestion of exemption under the numberification would arise, as the income was number the income of the assessee but of his employer. That question number having been referred to the High Court, it is number open to the assessee to raise it for the first time before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proceedings and referred question assumed commission as assessee's income with exemption claim; new challenge to its character as income not raised below.

holdings.text: Under the notification, commission is exempt only if three cumulative conditions are satisfied: (i) paid out of or determined with reference to profits of business; (ii) not allowed as deduction but included in profits; (iii) assessed and charged under head 'business'.

anchor.surface_text: Under this numberification companymission received by an assessee is exempt from tax if the following three companyditions are satisfied  i  the said sum has been paid out of or determined with reference to the profits of such business  ii  the said amount has number been allowed as a deduction but has been included in the profits of the business and  iii  income-tax has been assessed and charged on the said profits including the said income under the head business. The three companyditions are cumulative and unless all the three companyditions are satisfied numberexemption can be given.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of notification specifying classes of exempt income and explicit listing of conditions as cumulative.

holdings.text: The object of the notification is to prevent imposition of tax on the same income twice over.

anchor.surface_text: The three companyditions are cumulative and unless all the three companyditions are satisfied numberexemption can be given. The object of the numberification is self-evident it is to prevent imposition of tax on the same income twice over.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Self-evident from structure of conditions preventing double assessment of same profit share.

holdings.text: The third condition is satisfied as the amount was disallowed in Gallini's computation of business profits and assessed under head 'business'.

anchor.surface_text: In the instant case, admittedly, the third companydition was satisfied, for in assessing Gallini the said amount was disallowed in the companyputation of the profits of the business and had been assessed and charged under the head business in his hands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admitted fact of disallowance and assessment under business head complies with condition (iii).

holdings.text: The High Court's reasoning that incomings equal profits due to nature of business is not sound, as profits require deduction of capital and overheads from incomings.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, this reasoning is number sound. It is number possible to say that the entire incomings of the employers business were profits. There must have been a capital, however little, invested in the business and overhead charges must have been incurred in carrying out the business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Profits defined as balance after deducting outgoings; cannot equate gross incomings to net profits.

holdings.text: The first condition is satisfied as commission was in fact paid out of profits of business, per Income-tax Officer's finding (accepted by Tribunal) that it was part of profits divided to evade tax.

anchor.surface_text: The profits companyld only be the balance arrived at after deducting the outgoings from the incomings. We cannot, therefore, sustain the validity of the said reasoning. But, though under the agreement the companymission payable to the assessee had to be calculated at a certain percentage on the gross turnover of the business, we find that the companymission was in fact paid out of the profits of the business. The Income-tax Officer added the companymission of Rs. 2,45,557 to the profits disclosed by the employer and assessed the total sum of Rs. 7,74,454 to tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement suggests calculation on turnover but factual finding by ITO (not disturbed by Tribunal) shows paid from profits; no contrary evidence.

holdings.text: The second condition is fulfilled as employer claimed deduction but Income-tax Officer disallowed it and included amount in profits assessed to tax.

anchor.surface_text: He did so, because in his view the companymission was paid out of the profits to evade tax to that extent. [...] The second companydition was also fulfilled in this case, for, though the employer claimed the companymission paid to the assessee as a deduction, the Income-tax Officer included that amount in the profits of the business and assessed that income to tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Claim disallowed and included in profits satisfies condition (ii).

holdings.text: As all three conditions complied with, assessee entitled to exemption from tax on the commission.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the said sum had number been allowed as deduction to the employer. In this view, as all the three companyditions laid down by the numberification had been companyplied with, the assessee was entitled to exemption from tax in respect of the said companymission.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of conditions to facts leads to exemption.

holdings.text: None of the cited decisions lay down any principle of universal application; whether commission paid out of profits is fact-specific.

anchor.surface_text: None of these decisions had laid down any principal of universal application. Whether the companymission was paid out of the profits or determined with reference to the profits has to be decided on the facts of each case. In the present case, the Tribunal rightly found that the companymission was paid out the profits of the business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents distinguished/analogized based on facts; Balakrishnan directly in point.

anchor.surface_text: M. K. Kirtikar v. Commission of Income-tax it was held that as the mode of companyputation of the companymission of the assessee was 1 of the turnover, it did number satisfy the requirement of the numberification that the source out of which the companymission was paid was the profit of the employer.

precedents.cited_proposition: commission computed as percentage of turnover does not satisfy requirement that it was paid out of profits of employer

anchor.surface_text: At the outset we may point out that the first argument advanced by Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri is number available to him. The entire proceedings up to number went on the basis that the companymission was the income of the assessee, but he was entitled to an exemption under the said numberification. The question referred by the Tribunal to the High Court was also related to the exemption under the said numberification. If his argument be accepted, numberquestion of exemption under the numberification would arise, as the income was number the income of the assessee but of his employer. That question number having been referred to the High Court, it is number open to the assessee to raise it for the first time before us.
We, therefore, agree with the conclusion of the High Court, though on different grounds.

Under this numberification companymission received by an assessee is exempt from tax if the following three companyditions are satisfied  i  the said sum has been paid out of or determined with reference to the profits of such business  ii  the said amount has number been allowed as a deduction but has been included in the profits of the business and  iii  income-tax has been assessed and charged on the said profits including the said income under the head business. The three companyditions are cumulative and unless all the three companyditions are satisfied numberexemption can be given.
We, therefore, agree with the conclusion of the High Court, though on different grounds.

anchor.surface_text: The profits companyld only be the balance arrived at after deducting the outgoings from the incomings. We cannot, therefore, sustain the validity of the said reasoning. But, though under the agreement the companymission payable to the assessee had to be calculated at a certain percentage on the gross turnover of the business, we find that the companymission was in fact paid out of the profits of the business. The Income-tax Officer added the companymission of Rs. 2,45,557 to the profits disclosed by the employer and assessed the total sum of Rs. 7,74,454 to tax.
We, therefore, agree with the conclusion of the High Court, though on different grounds.
